<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="interventions">Interventions<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#interventions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ul>
<li>
<p>Establish and maintain record of frequency and characteristics of bowel movements.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Ensure patient consumes at least 1,300 mL fluids daily (unless contraindicated).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Review dietary pattern with patient and educate as needed regarding the inclusion of high-fiber foods in diet; monitor dietary intake.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assist patient in developing a program to increase activity level as appropriate.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assist patient in developing a regular schedule for toileting; provide toileting assistance as needed; ensure privacy is provided during toileting; if bedpan must be used, be sure patient is in upright position, unless contraindicated, and made comfortable.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consider use of herbs with laxative effects, such as aloe, dandelion root, cascara sagrada, senna, and rhubarb.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Consult with physician regarding use of vitamin C supplements several times daily until stool is soft (not to exceed 5,000 mg/d).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Administer laxatives, as prescribed; avoid long-term use of laxatives unless patient’s condition warrants otherwise.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Monitor for fecal impaction.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Assess patient’s use of laxatives and enemas; if dependency on laxatives or enemas for bowel elimination exists, educate patient about hazards associated with this dependency and develop a plan to gradually taper usage of laxative or enema (abrupt discontinuation is contraindicated).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Educate patient as to nonpharmacologic means to stimulate bowel movement.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Inactive lifestyle</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Low fiber and low fluid intake</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Depression</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Laxative abuse</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Certain medications, such as opiates, sedatives, and aluminum hydroxide gels</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dulled sensations that cause the signal for bowel elimination to be missed</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Failure to allow sufficient time for complete emptying of the bowel</p>
</li>
</ul>
<p>A diet high in fiber and fluid and regular activity can promote bowel elimination, and particular foods that patients find effective (e.g., prunes or chocolate pudding) can be incorporated into the regular diet. A mixture of raisins, prunes, dates, and currants can be a nourishing, tasty snack that promotes bowel elimination. (For individuals with chewing impairments, this can be blended with yogurt or applesauce.) Providing a regular time for bowel elimination is often helpful; mornings tend to be the best time for older adults to empty their bowels. Sometimes rocking the trunk from side to side and back and forth while sitting on the toilet will stimulate a bowel movement. Only after these measures have failed should medications be considered.</p>
<p>7</p>
<p>KEY CONCEPT</p>
<p>Measures to promote bowel elimination include scheduling a regular time for this function, incorporating high-fiber foods into the diet, and rocking the trunk from side to side and back and forth while sitting on the toilet.</p>
<p>Older persons may need education concerning bowel elimination. The safe use of laxatives should be emphasized to prevent laxative abuse. The patient should be aware that diarrhea resulting from laxative abuse may cause dehydration, a serious threat to life. Dandelion root, cascara sagrada, senna, and rhubarb are herbs that stimulate bowel movement and can be taken to prevent constipation.</p>
<p>Older adults in a hospital or nursing home may benefit from an elimination chart that reflects the time, amount, and characteristics of bowel movements. This chart can help the nurse prevent constipation and fecal impaction by providing easily accessible data regarding bowel elimination. Even older persons in the community can benefit from the use of an elimination record that they can maintain themselves.</p>
<p>Chronic constipation that does not improve with the usual measures may require medical evaluation, including anal, rectal, and sigmoid examinations, to determine the presence of any underlying cause.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="flatulence">Flatulence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#flatulence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Flatulence, which is common in older adults, is caused by constipation, irregular bowel movements, certain foods (e.g., the high-fiber foods promoted for increased dietary intake in recent years), and poor neuromuscular control of the anal sphincter. Achieving a regular bowel pattern and avoiding flatus-producing foods may relieve this problem, as may the administration of specific medications intended for this purpose. Sitting upright after meals is helpful in allowing gas to rise to the fundus of the stomach and be expelled.</p>
<p>Discomfort associated with the inability to expel flatus can occur occasionally. Increased activity can provide relief, as may a knee-chest position, if possible. A flatus bag consisting of a rectal tube with an attached plastic bag that prevents the entrance of air into the rectum can be beneficial.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="intestinal-obstruction">Intestinal Obstruction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#intestinal-obstruction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Partial or complete impairment of flow of intestinal contents in the large intestines most often occurs due to cancer of the colon; adhesions and hernias are the primary cause of obstructions in the small intestine. Other causes of blockage include diverticulitis, ulcerative colitis, hypokalemia, vascular problems, and paralytic ileus, a mechanical obstruction that can occur following surgery due to nerves being affected by the extended lack of peristaltic activity.</p>
<p>Symptoms vary depending on the site and cause of the obstruction:</p>
<ul>
<li>Small bowel obstruction causes upper and mid-abdominal pain in rhythmic recurring waves related to the small intestine's attempt to push the contents through the obstruction. Vomiting occurs and may bring some relief.</li>
<li>Obstructions occurring past the ileum cause abdominal distension so severe that the raised diaphragm can inhibit respirations. Vomiting is more severe than with small bowel blockages and initially is composed of semidigested food and later contains bile and is more watery.</li>
<li>Obstruction of the colon causes lower abdominal pain, altered bowel habits, distension, and a sensation of the need to defecate. Vomiting usually does not occur until late, when the distension reaches the small intestine.</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="consider-this-case">CONSIDER THIS CASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#consider-this-case" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251227-05b2fc9d.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg"></p>
<p>Mr. C is a 75-year-old participant in an adult day care program. In interviewing him, you learn that he had a cerebrovascular accident 2 years ago that left him with some right-sided weakness. His medical record indicates that he also has a history of hiatal hernia, depression, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. He is taking antihypertensive, antidepressant, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="think-critically">THINK CRITICALLY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#think-critically" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<ol>
<li>What threats to gastrointestinal health exist for Mr. C?</li>
<li>What measures could be taken to reduce those threats?</li>
</ol>
<p>The nurse should review symptoms thoroughly and note bowel sounds. Bowel obstruction can cause high-pitched peristaltic rushes to be heard on auscultation. If the obstruction has persisted for a long time or the bowel has been significantly damaged, bowel sounds decrease and eventually are absent.</p>
<p>Timely intervention is essential to prevent bowel strangulation and serious complications. X-rays and blood evaluation typically are done to determine the cause and extent of the problem. Intestinal intubation is the</p>
<p>major treatment and often helps to decompress the bowel and allow the obstruction to be broken. If medical management is unsuccessful or if the cause is due to vascular or mechanical obstructions, surgery is required. In addition to supporting the medical or surgical treatment plan, nurses need to promote the patient's comfort and ensure that fluid and electrolyte balance is restored and maintained.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fecal-impaction">Fecal Impaction<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fecal-impaction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Prevention of constipation aids in avoiding fecal impaction. Observing the frequency and character of bowel movements may aid in detecting the development of an impaction; a bowel elimination record is essential for older people in a hospital or nursing home for identifying alternations in bowel elimination. Indications of a fecal impaction include the following:</p>
<ul>
<li>Distended rectum</li>
<li>Abdominal and rectal discomfort</li>
<li>Oozing of fecal material around the impaction, often mistaken as diarrhea</li>
<li>Palpable, hard fecal mass</li>
<li>Fever</li>
</ul>
<p>Because policies may vary, nurses should review the permissive procedures of their employing agency to ensure that removal of a fecal impaction is an acceptable nursing action. An enema, usually oil retention, may be prescribed to assist in the softening and elimination process. Manual breaking and removal of feces with a lubricated gloved finger will promote removal of the impaction. Sometimes, injecting 50 mL hydrogen peroxide through a rectal tube will cause breakage of the impaction as the hydrogen peroxide foams. Care should be taken not to traumatize or overexert the patient during these procedures.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="fecal-incontinence">Fecal Incontinence<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fecal-incontinence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Involuntary defecation, fecal incontinence, refers to the inability to voluntarily control the passage of stool. It is most often associated with fecal impaction in older adults who are institutionalized or physically or</p>
<p>cognitively impaired. For this reason, the initial step is to assess for the presence of an impaction. If an impaction is not present, the nurse must assess for other causes. Possible causes of bowel incontinence include decreased contractile strength, impaired automaticity of the puborectal and external anal sphincter (secondary to age-related muscle weakness or injury to the pudendal nerve), loss of cortical control, and reduced reservoir capacity (secondary to surgical resection or the presence of a tumor). Proctosigmoidoscopy, proctography, and anorectal manometry are among the diagnostic tests used to evaluate this disorder. The cause of the incontinence dictates the treatment approach, which could include bowel retraining (NURSING CARE PLAN 18-2), drugs, surgery, or biofeedback.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="nursing-care-plan-18-2">NURSING CARE PLAN 18-2<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nursing-care-plan-18-2" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="the-older-adult-with-fecal-incontinence">THE OLDER ADULT WITH FECAL INCONTINENCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#the-older-adult-with-fecal-incontinence" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Nursing Problem: Fecal incontinence</p>
<table><thead><tr><th>Goal</th><th>Nursing Actions</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td>The patient achieves partial or complete restoration of bowel control.</td><td>- Record and evaluate patient's bowel elimination pattern.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ul>
<li>Establish consistent time to toilet based on pattern.</li>
<li>Position patient in best physiologic position for bowel movement: sitting with normal posture.</li>
<li>Have patient lean forward or prop feet on stool to increase intra-abdominal pressure.</li>
<li>Instruct patient to bear down and attempt to defecate.</li>
<li>Record results; ensure patient does not develop fecal impaction.</li>
<li>If necessary, stimulate anorectal reflex with glycerin suppository 30–45 minutes before scheduled bowel movement.</li>
<li>Supplement toilet activities with exercise and good fluid (minimally 1,500 mL/d) and fiber intake unless contraindicated.  |</li>
</ul>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-appendicitis">Acute Appendicitis<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-appendicitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Although acute appendicitis does not occur frequently in older persons, it is important to note that it may present with altered signs and symptoms if it does occur. The severe pain that occurs in younger persons may be absent in older adults, whose pain may be minimal and referred. Fever may be minimal, and leukocytosis may be absent. These differences often cause a delayed diagnosis. Prompt surgery will improve the patient's prognosis.</p>
<p>Unfortunately, delayed or missed diagnosis and the inability to improve the general status of the patient before this emergency surgery can lead to greater complications and mortality in older persons with appendicitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cancer-of-the-pancreas">Cancer of the Pancreas<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cancer-of-the-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Pancreatic cancer primarily affects older adults, peaking between ages 70 and 79 years, and is difficult to detect until it has reached an advanced stage. Anorexia, weakness, weight loss, and wasting are generalized symptoms easily attributed to other causes. Dyspepsia, belching, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, and obstructive jaundice may occur as well. Fever may or may not be present. The person may experience epigastric pain radiating to the back. This pain is relieved when the person leans forward and is worsened when a recumbent position is assumed. Surgery is performed to treat this problem. Unfortunately, the disease is generally so advanced by the time diagnosis is made that the prognosis is usually poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="biliary-tract-disease">Biliary Tract Disease<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#biliary-tract-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Cholelithiasis, the formation or presence of gallstones in the gallbladder, increases with age and affects women more frequently than men. Pain, often following meals, is the primary symptom. Treatment measures include nonsurgical therapies, such as rotary lithotrite treatment and extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy, and the standard surgical procedures. Obstruction, inflammation, and infection are potential outcomes of gallstones and require monitoring.</p>
<p>Cancer of the gallbladder primarily affects older persons, especially women. Fortunately, this disease does not occur frequently. Pain in the right upper quadrant, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, jaundice, weakness, and constipation are the usual symptoms. Although surgery may be performed, the prognosis for the patient with cancer of the gallbladder is poor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="bringing-research-to-life">BRINGING RESEARCH TO LIFE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bringing-research-to-life" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="association-between-oral-health-and-frailty-a-systematic-review-of-longitudinal-studies">Association Between Oral Health and Frailty: A Systematic Review of Longitudinal Studies<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#association-between-oral-health-and-frailty-a-systematic-review-of-longitudinal-studies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Source: Hakeem, F. F., Bernabe, E., &amp; Sabbah, W. (2019). Gerodontology, 36(3), 205–215.</p>
<p>The status of one’s teeth and oral cavity in general can impact physical, emotional, and social health. Because of this relationship, geriatric health care professionals have traditionally viewed poor oral health as a cause of a decline in health that could lead to frailty; however, evidence supporting this view has been scarce. This study sought to find longitudinal studies that could support the association between oral health and frailty in older adults.</p>
<p>The researchers found five longitudinal studies that explored the relationship between oral health and frailty. Oral health indicators used included number of teeth present, evidence of periodontal disease, ability to bite and chew food, use of dentures, and presence of dry mouth, or oral health problems. Frailty was measured using Fried’s frailty phenotype criteria. The review showed significant relationships between oral health indicators and frailty.</p>
<p>Frailty significantly alters the quality of life and functional ability of older adults. Poor oral health is a cause of frailty that can be prevented. Instructing older adults in good oral health practices and encouraging regular dental examination are important measures that can be included in routine nurse-patient contacts. Older adults who are unable to independently provide their own oral hygiene should be assisted to ensure their oral health is not threatened. Although this may seem like a basic measure, encouraging—and, when necessary, providing—good oral hygiene can significantly impact the health, function, and quality of life of older adults.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="practice-realities">PRACTICE REALITIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#practice-realities" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A local church with a membership of more than 2,000 people has initiated a health ministry program and surveyed their members to assess needs. One of the findings of the survey was that less than 10% of the adults older than 60 years of age had ever had a colonoscopy. All of the respondents had insurance that could cover the cost of the procedure so financial hardship wasn't an obstacle.</p>
<p>The church asks you to assist them in developing a campaign to encourage colorectal screening.</p>
<p>What would you envision the components of this program to be?</p>
<p>What strategies could stimulate interest of the church members?</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="critical-thinking-exercises">CRITICAL THINKING EXERCISES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#critical-thinking-exercises" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<ol>
<li>What age-related changes affect bowel elimination?</li>
<li>Describe the changes in dental care that have occurred since today's older adults were children and the way in which this will affect dental health of future generations of older persons.</li>
<li>What preventive measures could you recommend to older adults to promote bowel elimination?</li>
<li>What are some actions that a nursing home could take to assess the presence of dysphagia and to monitor their residents for new or worsening of dysphagia symptoms on an ongoing basis?</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="next-generation-nclex-style-case-study-and-questions">NEXT GENERATION NCLEX-STYLE CASE STUDY AND QUESTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#next-generation-nclex-style-case-study-and-questions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Below is a case study for this chapter in the Next Generation NCLEX style. See online Appendix A for the Next Generation NCLEX questions related to this case study, and see online Appendix B for the answers to those questions.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="df2bb471">The nurse is completing a direct admission assessment of an 80-year-old female client on a telemetry unit. Nurse’s Notes<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#df2bb471" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>1300: The client is brought to the unit accompanied by her son directly from her primary healthcare provider’s office. The client states that she started feeling severe abdominal cramping in her lower abdomen that has lasted for 3 days. She further indicates that the pain became unbearable and sharp in nature, so she called her son and asked him to drive her to her doctor’s office. During the office visit, she becomes diaphoretic, starts to vomit, and begins to experience chest pain. The client reports being otherwise healthy except for occasional heartburn spells that started 6 months ago.</p>
<p>Her primary healthcare provider quickly decides to admit her to the telemetry unit for an overnight observation. The admitting orders are as follows: place on telemetry, protoxin 20 mg IV daily, and Tylenol 650 mg suppository every 6 hours as needed for pain. Labs ordered include cardiac enzymes STAT and CBC (complete metabolic profile). Keep patient NPO for stress test in the morning. Home medications include calcium 2,000 mg/d and antacids over the counter. Client indicates that she takes the antacids frequently for her heartburn and doubles the dose of her calcium consumption because of occasional joint pain.</p>
<p>1500: The nurse notes that the client’s abdomen is distended and difficult to palpate. Client indicates that she doesn’t remember the last time she had a bowel movement but thinks it was sometime last week. Client reports burning stomach pain and belching with frequent hiccups. Vital signs: temperature 99.0°F oral, pulse 120, respirations 20, blood pressure 120/76, bedside blood glucose level 70 mg/dL, and pulse oximetry 99% on room air. The client’s weight is 97 lb. She indicates that she has lost 15 lb within the last month; she has been eating less because it hurts to chew. The nurse notes that the client’s teeth have various degrees of erosion, abrasions of crown and root structure, and high prevalence of tooth loss. Client indicates that she does not like drinking water but drinks a nutritional shake that her primary healthcare provider ordered</p>
<p>because of her weight loss. Client is tentatively diagnosed with possible myocardial infarction, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), peptic ulcer disease (PUD), and gastritis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-summary">Chapter Summary<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-summary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Although most of the gastrointestinal problems experienced by older adults are not life threatening, they can significantly affect the quality of life and health status of this population, thereby making their effective management important. Some gastrointestinal conditions can be prevented by good health practices, including regular oral hygiene, sound dietary practices, regular bowel elimination, and prompt attention to symptoms.</p>
<p>Gastrointestinal symptoms, although common, can indicate serious medical problems in older adults and need to be taken seriously. Conditions such as xerostomia, dysphagia, hiatal hernia, esophageal cancer, peptic ulcer, cholelithiasis, and cancer of the stomach, colon, and pancreas occur with greater frequency in older adults. Diagnosis of these problems can be difficult because of atypical symptomatology, self-medication that masks symptoms, and easy confusion with disorders of other systems. Astute questioning and alertness to subtle symptoms during the assessment can help these conditions to be diagnosed and treated early.</p>

<p>CHAPTER 19</p>
<p>Urinary Elimination</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="chapter-outline">Chapter Outline<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chapter-outline" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
